questions.text: A college-going student presents to you with the rapidly increasing power of glasses due to progressive myopia. You also noticed the following sign, when the patient was asked to look in a downward gaze. The ophthalmic examination in this patient usually reveals all the following signs except _______
questions.solution:
Haab's striae are not seen in keratoconus.

Haab’s striae are tears and breaks in Descemet's membrane seen in Congenital glaucoma.

Keratoconus is a progressive disorder in which central or paracentral corneal stromal thinning occurs, accompanied by apical protrusion and irregular astigmatism. Vogt's striae are seen in the keratoconus.

Keratoconus presents with the features of rapidly increasing power of the glasses and localised bulging of the lower lid when the patient looks down.

The signs seen in keratoconus:

  • Direct ophthalmoscopy from a distance of half a meter shows a fairly well-delineated oil droplet reflex
  • Fleischer's ring: Iron deposition on the epithelium
  • Munson’s Sign: V-shaped deformity of the lower lid on downward gaze (as shown in the image )
  • Scissoring reflex in retinoscopy
  • Vogt’s striae:  Vertical (rarely horizontal) fine, whitish lines in the deep/posterior stroma and Descemet's membrane.

Related Pearl: Vogt's striae

The above image shows “Vogt’s Striae” which are characteristically seen in Keratoconus.

  • Vogt's striae are vertical (rarely horizontal) fine, whitish lines in the deep/posterior stroma and Descemet's membrane commonly found in patients with keratoconus.
  • It may be asymmetric depending on the degree of keratoconus in each eye.
  • It is considered that there is a positive correlation between the orientation of the lines with the steepest axis of the cornea and the mechanism is thought to be related to mechanical stress forces on collagen lamellae radiating from the cone apex.
  • The striae can temporarily disappear with external pressure to the globe.

questions.text:
A middle-aged man presents with progressive difficulty in swallowing both solids and liquids for 8 months. A barium swallow was done and is given below. Upper GI endoscopy was normal. Which of the following correctly describes the manometric evaluation of this disorder?

IRP: integrated relaxation pressure
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and barium swallow image showing a bird beak appearance is suggestive of achalasia cardia. It is characterized by high median IRP and absent peristalsis.

Disorders of esophageal motility can be classified as:

Disorders of esophago-gastric junction (EGJ) outflow: elevated IRP

  • Achalasia cardia: elevated IRP and peristalsis absent
  • EGJ outflow obstruction: elevated IRP and peristalsis present

Disorders of peristalsis: normal IRP

  • Absent contractility
  • Distal esophageal spasm
  • Hypercontractile esophagus

Achalasia cardia occurs due to the loss of inhibitory ganglion cells in the myenteric plexus of GIT. During swallowing, the food bolus normally triggers a primary peristaltic wave, which is responsible for carrying the bolus to the stomach. This is accompanied by relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) to allow esophageal emptying into the stomach. Achalasia is characterized by a disruption of this normal process. Failure of relaxation of the LES causes an elevated median IRP. Moreover, there is a complete failure of peristalsis. The esophagus becomes progressively more tortuous, leading to megaesophagus.

On upper GI scopy, achalasia can show accumulated saliva or food residue in the lower part of the esophagus, but is often reported normal. Upper GI scopy is an important investigation to rule out a mechanical cause of progressive dysphagia, such as a malignancy. Barium contrast studies show a hold-up of the contrast material in the distal esophagus, giving rise to the bird beak appearance.

Related Pearl: Achalasia Cardia

Achalasia cardia is a rare disease caused by the loss of ganglion cells within the esophageal myenteric plexus. Their absence leads to increased tone of the lower esophageal sphincter, impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES), and absent peristalsis.

Achalasia is the only true motility disorder of the esophagus.

  • Primary achalasia is due to ganglion cell degeneration and is thought to be due to an autoimmune process attributable to latent infection with human herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV1) combined with genetic susceptibility.
  • Secondary achalasia may arise in Chaga's disease.

Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia (solid and liquid food)
  • Regurgitation
  • Chest pain
  • Weight loss
  • Bronchitis, pneumonia, or lung abscess from aspiration

Differential diagnosis: Diffuse esophageal spasm, pseudoachalasia

On barium swallow: Bird beak-appearance

Investigation of choice: Manometry (most sensitive)

Treatment: Pneumatic dilatation, Heller myotomy

questions.text: A 50-year-old diabetic female patient presents to you with complaints of greenish nipple discharge for the past few months. Examination reveals the presence of discharge from multiple ducts with para-areolar lump and advised for mammography. Which of the following mammography findings, you would expect in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of duct ectasia and mammogram of a patient with duct ectasia shows typical Broken-needle type of calcification.  This is due to the calcification of debris within dilated ducts.

Duct ectasia is the dilatation of breast ducts. It is the most common cause of nipple discharge in nonlactating women. This condition is associated with smoking and diabetes.

The initial stage of this disease consists of dilatation of one or more lactiferous ducts. These ducts get filled with stagnant brown or green colored secretions. In the later stages, the accumulation of fluid in the lactiferous ducts leads to infection and inflammation, causing periductal mastitis. The infections are most often mixed infections of aerobic and anaerobic flora of the skin.

Initial episodes can be managed with antibiotics. Recurrent episodes of the disease are best managed by Hadfield operation.

Other options:

  • Popcorn calcification is seen in fibroadenoma.
  • Egg-shell calcification is seen in traumatic fat necrosis.
  • Tea-cup calcification is seen in fibrocystic disease.

Popcorn calcification:

Egg-shell calcification:

Broken-needle type of calcification:

Tea-cup calcification-On a lateral magnification view, layering of calcific fluid contained within microcysts can be appreciated, producing a characteristic ‘teacup’ appearance.

Related Pearl: Discharge from the Nipple

    • Duct ectasia
  • Serous (any colour):

  • Serous:

  • Milk:
    • Lactation
    • Rare causes (hypothyroidism, pituitary tumour)

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient with atrial fibrillation complains of sudden onset weakness of the right lower limb, with urinary and faecal incontinence. MRI shows an ischaemic stroke involving the left anterior cerebral artery. Which of the following features would you not expect to see in this patient?
questions.solution:
Prosopagnosia, also called face blindness, is the inability to recognize faces including one's own image. This occurs due to occipitotemporal lobe damage, seen in posterior cerebral artery (PCA) strokes involving cortical branch occlusion.
It is not seen in anterior cerebral artery strokes. 

The anterior cerebral artery (ACA) supplies parts of the frontal lobe, corpus callosum, paracentral lobule, and other deeper structures.

Signs and symptoms of ACA occlusion and structures involved:

  • Urinary incontinence, fecal incontinence
  • Paratonic rigidity
  • Abulia (Akinetic mutism), lack of spontaneity, slowness
  • Gait impairment
  • Paralysis of contralateral foot and leg
  • Paresis of the contralateral arm
  • Cortical sensory loss over the contralateral lower limb
  • Dyspraxia of left limbs, tactile aphasia in left limbs.

questions.text: You are assisting a surgeon performing a hepatic surgery and during the procedure, you suddenly encounter a significant amount of bleeding. To control the blood loss,  where should the clamp be applied?
questions.solution:
The clamp will be applied at the porta hepatis to minimize the blood loss.

Pringle maneuver: Rapid control of the vessels entering the porta hepatis can be obtained by compressing them in the free edge of the lesser omentum.

Porta hepatis is a deep, transverse fissure that is situated on the inferior surface of the right lobe of the liver.

Structures entering at porta hepatis:

  • Portal vein
  • Hepatic artery
  • Hepatic nervous plexus

Structures exiting the porta hepatis:

  • Right and left hepatic bile ducts
  • Lymphatics

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presents with pain in the right hypochondrium and fever. He is also having mild jaundice. ERCP showed linear smooth filling defects. Which among the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and linear smooth filling defects on ERCP is suggestive of worm in the biliary tree.

The worm may also be seen as parallel filling defects - railway track sign. Worms in the gall-bladder appear as the long tubular coiled echogenic structure which may be rapidly mobile and is easier to diagnose than biliary ductal ascariasis.

Ultrasonography is also highly sensitive and specific to detect worms in biliary tree. USG is not useful to detect worms in duodenum or ampullary orifice.

questions.text:
A child with ambiguous genitalia was diagnosed with 21 hydroxylase deficiency. Choose the correct statements which can be mentioned to the concerned parents about the management of the condition.
  1. Glucocorticoid treatment minimizes virilization and excessive growth
  2. Steroid treatment is continued till surgery is undertaken
  3. Doses should be reduced if the child develops an infection
  4. Inadequate corticosteroid therapy can lead to testicular tumours in males
  5. Surgical treatment is done between 2-6 months of age
questions.solution:
Statements 1, 4 and 5 are the correct statements about the treatment of Congenital adrenal hyperplasia due to 21 hydroxylase deficiency.

Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH)/adrenogenital syndrome is a family of autosomal-recessive disorders associated with the diminished synthesis of cortisol and aldosterone. The most common cause of ambiguous genitalia in a newborn is a classic 21-hydroxylase deficiency.

Virilization is usually apparent at birth in females and within 2 to 3 years of life in males. 

Management:

Glucocorticoids are the mainstay of treatment and are continued indefinitely for those with the classical disease. It treats cortisol deficiency and also suppresses excessive production of androgens, minimizing excessive growth and skeletal maturation, and virilization. Patients with salt-wasting and virilizing forms are treated with hydrocortisone and fludrocortisone.

During periods of stress- such as infections or surgery, double or triple doses are indicated.

Males with 21-hydroxylase deficiency who have had inadequate corticosteroid therapy may develop testicular adrenal rest tumors. These usually regress following increased steroid dosage.

Surgical treatment is usually done between 2-6 months of age for significantly virilized females. 

Related Pearl: Variants of Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH)

Deficiency of cortisol and sex hormones

Deficiency of cortisol

Deficiency of cortisol, aldosterone, and testosterone

↑ in testosterone

Salt retention and  hypertension

Virilization of females (ambiguous genitalia 46XX)     Failure of sexual development in females at puberty Virilization of females  (ambiguous genitalia 46XX) Females are mildly
virilized (DHEA is a weak androgen)
Precocious puberty in males Males are incompletely virilized (ambiguous genitalia 46XY) Precocious puberty in males Males are incompletely virilized (ambiguous genitalia 46XY)

Note: In 11β-hydroxylase deficiency, aldosterone synthetic capacity is normal and some corticosterone is synthesized from progesterone by intact aldosterone synthase enzyme. Thus, it is unusual for patients to manifest signs of adrenal insufficiency.

questions.text: A 43-year-old lady presents to the OPD with complaints of pain in her left hand.  On examination, there is swelling and tenderness over the radial styloid. The test shown in the image below results in acute pain, resulting from the involvement of the structures marked as A and B. Identify the structures.

choices.text: A- Abductor pollicis longus and B- Extensor pollicis brevis
A -Extensor pollicis longus and B- abductor pollicis brevis
A- Abductor pollicis brevis and B- Extensor pollicis brevis
A- Extensor pollicis brevis and B- abductor pollicis longus

questions.solution:
The probable diagnosis is De Quervain's disease, which is a stenosing tenosynovitis of the extensor tendons of the first dorsal compartment, namely extensor pollicis brevis (marked as A) and abductor pollicis longus (marked as B). It is prominent among females, especially women of childbearing age.

The image shows Eichhof's test: performed by asking the patient to place the thumb within their palm and clench it with the other fingers after which the wrist is passively ulnar flexed by the examiner. 

It is positive in the following conditions:

  • De Quervain's tenosynovitis
  • Arthritis in the intercarpal and radiocarpal joints
  • Superficial radial nerve entrapment 
  • Intersection syndrome- A tenosynovitis occurring due to friction between the obliquely placed extensor and abductor pollicis tendons, and the longitudinally placed extensor tendons.

Other clinical features of De Quervain's disease include visible swelling over the radial styloid, palpable thickening of the tendon sheath, tenderness at the tip of the radial styloid and pain on resisted thumb extension (hitch-hiker’s sign).

Treatment:

  • The majority of the patients are treated conservatively with steroid injection and splinting.
  • Few require surgical release of the 1st dorsal compartment (housing the APL and EPB tendons).

questions.text: A patient with erectile dysfunction did not respond to PDE-5 inhibitor drugs. A second-line treatment involves the injection of prostaglandin into the part of the penis marked as X in the image below. Which is the prostaglandin used?
questions.solution:
The part marked as X in the image is the corpus cavernosum and prostaglandin indicated for direct intracavernosal injection for erectile dysfunction is PGE1- Alprostadil.

It is a natural PGE1 preparation available as an intraurethral suppository and intracavernosal injection. It is usually used in patients who are not responding to PDE-5 inhibitors such as those with neurogenic and psychogenic erectile dysfunction.

Side effects of alprostadil include pain, bruising, and priapism. If priapism occurs, the patient will need urgent medical attention, which might include aspiration of blood, surgical shunt, or intracavernosal injection of phenylephrine for cavernosal vasoconstriction.

Alprostadil is also used for temporarily maintaining the patency of a patent ductus arteriosus in neonates.

Management of Erectile dysfunction:

  • Lifestyle modifications
  • First-line pharmacological therapy consists of PDE-5 inhibitors like sildenafil, vardenafil, tadalafil.
    • Common side effects include headache, flushing, dyspepsia, nasal congestion, dizziness, and back pain. Blue green-tinted vision and blurred vision may be experienced with sildenafil and vardenafil. Priapism leading to ischemia may also occur.
    • PDE5 inhibitors potentiate the hypotensive effects of nitrates, leading to hypotension. It is contraindicated in patients receiving organic nitrates.
    • CYP3A inhibitors (e.g., protease inhibitors, erythromycin, and cimetidine) inhibit the metabolism of PDE5 inhibitors and elevate their blood levels.
  • Vacuum erection devices: A cylindrical device placed over the penis and then pumped. It creates a negative pressure vacuum to draw blood into the penis. Side effects include petechiae, hematomas, grey-blue color to the penis.
  • Second-line therapy:
    • Intracavernosal injection (ICI) of vasoactive substances like prostaglandin E1, papaverine, and phentolamine. They work alone or in combination to elicit an erection. Prostaglandin PGE1 has been approved by the FDA as a single-agent ICI for erectile dysfunction to increase cAMP levels.
    • Intraurethral suppository of a prostaglandin E1: Can be inserted into the urethra before intercourse. 
  • Surgical methods: Penile implants and penile revascularization. 

Other Prostaglandins/ Prosatglandin analogs:

  • PGE1 analog: Misoprostol is approved for termination of pregnancy, and the prevention of NSAID induced gastric ulcers.
  • PGE2: Dinoprostone is used for cervical ripening, induction of labor, and as abortifacients in the second trimester of pregnancy.
  • PGI2: Epoprostenol improves symptoms and delays the need for lung or heart-lung transplantation in Pulmonary artery hypertension.
  • PGI2 analogs: Iloprost and Treprostinil used in the management of pulmonary artery hypertension.
  • PGF2α: Carboprost is used to induce second-trimester abortions and to control postpartum hemorrhage. Latanoprost is a long-acting PGF2α derivative, used for glaucoma. Similar prostanoids with ocular hypotensive effects include bimatoprost, tafluprost, and travoprost.

questions.text:
A patient admitted for hemoptysis experienced a bout of coughing, during which his blood-stained secretions came in contact with the nurse's eyes. On further probing, the patient revealed that he had been on antiretroviral therapy for 1 year. Identify the incorrect statements about post-exposure prophylaxis in this case.
  1. Two drug regime is followed since exposure is mild
  2. It should be certainly started within 72 hours of exposure
  3. It should be continued for 28 days
  4. She should undergo a test for HIV up till 6 weeks post-exposure
  5. Blood donation is allowed once PEP is completed
questions.solution:
1, 4 and 5 are the incorrect statements.

Post Exposure Prophylaxis (PEP) for HIV should be initiated as early as possible, to all individuals with exposure ideally within 2 hours (but certainly within the first 72 hours) of exposure.

Exposures that may warrant occupational PEP include:

Parenteral or mucous membrane exposure (splashes to the eye, nose, or oral cavity. The following bodily fluids may pose a risk of HIV infection: blood, blood-stained saliva, breast milk, genital secretions, and cerebrospinal, amniotic, rectal, peritoneal, synovial, pericardial, or pleural fluids.

Exposures that do not require PEP include:

  • When the exposed individual is already HIV-positive
  • When the source is established to be HIV-negative
  • Exposure to bodily fluids that do not pose a significant risk: tears, non-blood-stained saliva, urine, and sweat.

3 drug PEP regimen is given irrespective of percutaneous or mucous membrane exposure and irrespective of mild, moderate or severe exposure. It is as follows:

        Drug combination   Recommendation for PEP         Duration
Tenofovir (TDF) 300 mg + Lamivudine(3TC) 300 mg + Dolutegravir (DTG) 50mg          Once daily          4 weeks

DTG is recommended as the preferred third drug for HIV post-exposure prophylaxis. When available, ATV/r, DRV/r, LPV/r and RAL may be considered as alternative third drug options for post-exposure prophylaxis.

Follow up: HIV antibody testing should be done for at least 6 months post-exposure (e.g. at baseline, 6 weeks, 3 months, and 6 months) to ensure no transmission has occurred. Blood donation should be avoided while the individual is taking PEP, and while still in the window period for HIV acquisition and testing.

questions.text: Identify the true statement about a polypeptide growth factor with an insulin-like activity. It is diminished or absent in African pygmies leading to the hereditary short stature.

choices.text: It is produced in the choroid plexus
It has a short half life as it is tightly bound
Secretion is dependent on growth hormone in fetus

questions.solution:
The pygmies of Africa have a small stature due to the congenital inability to synthesize significant amounts of somatomedin C or IGF-1, the levels of which peak at puberty.

Somatomedins are polypeptide growth factors secreted by the liver and other tissues, under the influence of growth hormone (GH). The only circulating somatomedins is insulin-like growth factor I (IGF-I, somatomedin C) and IGF-II. They are tightly bound to plasma proteins, prolonging their half-life in the circulation, with a longer duration of action than growth hormone. (Half-life is around 20 hours, compared to that of GH which is 20 minutes)

IGF-I secretion is independent of growth hormone before birth but is stimulated by growth hormone after birth. Its levels rise in plasma during childhood, reach a peak at puberty, and then decline to low levels in old age. Some effects of IGF-1 are:

  • Bone and cartilage growth
  • Protein synthesis
  • Insulin-like activity
  • Anti lipolytic activity

Clinical significance:

  • African pygmies: Normal growth hormone levels, a slight reduction in growth hormone-binding protein levels. Congenital inability to synthesize significant amounts of plasma IGF-I and concentration fails to increase at puberty.
  • Growth hormone insensitivity or Laron dwarfism: Plasma IGF-I and its binding protein are reduced in this type of dwarfism

questions.text: The image given below is the structure of aggrecan, which is the principal proteoglycan found in cartilage. Identify the three glycosaminoglycans which are labeled as A, B, and C respectively.

choices.text: Hyaluronic acid, keratan sulfate, and chondroitin sulfate
Chondroitin sulfate, dermatan sulfate, and keratan sulfate
Hyaluronic acid, keratan sulfate, and heparan sulfate
Heparan sulfate, chondroitin sulphate, and keratan sulfate

questions.solution:
Aggrecan contains glycosaminoglycans hyaluronic acid, chondroitin sulfate, and keratan sulfate along with link and core proteins. It is the principal proteoglycan found in cartilage.

Various glycosaminoglycans include: 

  • Hyaluronic acid: Present in the extracellular matrix of nearly all tissues, but more concentrated in the skin and umbilical cord, bone, cartilage, joints (synovial fluid), vitreous humor in the eye, as well as in embryonic tissues. It plays a role in cell migration during morphogenesis and wound repair. The high concentrations of hyaluronic acid together with chondroitin sulfates in the cartilage contribute to its compressibility.
  • Chondroitin Sulfates (Chondroitin 4-Sulfate & Chondroitin 6-Sulfate): The repeating disaccharide units are GlcUA and GalNAc. They maintain the structure of the extracellular matrix and are located in endochondral bone and cartilage. They are also found in high amounts in the ECM of the central nervous system. In addition to their structural function, they act as signaling molecules in the prevention of the repair of nerve endings after injury.
  • Keratan Sulfates I & II: They consist of repeating Gal-GlcNAc disaccharide units. They are found in the cornea and in the cartilage. Keratin sulfate I or II are differentiated based on the different linkage to the core protein. They play a critical role in corneal transparency. Changes in the proteoglycan composition are seen in corneal scars.
  • Heparin: Heparin is found in the granules of mast cells and also in the liver, lung, and skin and is an important anticoagulant. It is released into the blood from capillary walls by the action of lipoprotein lipase and it binds with factors IX and XI. Its most important interaction is with plasma antithrombin.
  • Heparan Sulfate: It is found on many extracellular cell surfaces. The predominant uronic acid is GlcUA. Heparan sulfates are associated with the plasma membrane of cells as receptors, and may also participate in the mediation of cell growth and cell-cell communication. It is also found in the basement membrane of the kidney and determines the charge selectiveness of glomerular filtration.
  • Dermatan Sulfate: Dermatan sulfate has a widespread distribution in tissues, and is the main GAG in the skin. It may also play a part in blood coagulation, wound repair, and resistance to infection.

questions.text:
Match the following innate immunity receptors with the products that they detect:
Receptors Detects
A. RIG-like receptors  1. Fungal glycans
B. C-type lectin receptors 2. Microbial sugars
C. Mannose receptors 3. Viral nucleic acids 
D. NOD-like receptor 4. Necrotic cells
questions.solution:
The correct answer is A-3, B-1, C-2, D-4

RIG-like receptors (RLRs), are present in the cytosol of a majority of cells and detect nucleic acids of viruses that replicate in the cytoplasm of the infected cells. These receptors also stimulate the production of antiviral cytokines.

Mannose receptors recognize microbial sugars which contain terminal mannose residues and induce phagocytosis of these microbes.

C-type lectin receptors (CLRs): Expressed on the plasma membrane of macrophages and dendritic cells. Detect fungal glycans and elicit inflammatory reactions to fungi.

NOD-like receptors (NLRs) are present in the cytosol, which recognize uric acid and released ATP (products of necrotic cells), ion disturbances (like loss of K+), and a few microbial products.

  1. Amiodarone

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman who was treated for COVID-19 one month back now presents with a black, foul-smelling discharge from the nose and suppuration of the left eye as shown below. There is significant visual impairment. On examination, there is a blackish necrotic mass filling the nasal cavity and eroding the septum and hard palate. Considering the suspected diagnosis, which of the following investigations would be done in her case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Mucormycosis. It can be isolated and cultured on Sabouraud's agar for diagnosis.

Mucormycosis is an opportunistic infection caused principally by species of rhizopus, mucor, and lichtheimia. Among them, the most prevalent species are Rhizopus oryzae and R. delemar. It is seen in patients with diabetes mellitus, leukemias, lymphomas, long-term corticosteroid use, severe burns, and immunodeficiencies.

The common clinical form is rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis in which there is an invasion of the blood vessels in the nasal cavity, eyes, and brain causing thrombosis, infarction, and necrosis. They invade the tissues of patients with reduced host defense. From there, they enter the blood vessels and proliferate in the walls of blood vessels particularly paranasal sinuses and orbit. The blackish discoloration is due to arterial and venous thrombosis leading to gangrene.

Invasive Mucormycosis has recently emerged as a life-threatening complication of COVID-19 in India. It is an opportunistic infection seen even in mild to moderate COVID patients with strong predisposing factors like hyperglycemia/uncontrolled diabetes. Diabetic patients receiving corticosteroids/immunosuppressants for COVID-19 treatment are exceptionally vulnerable to develop mucormycosis due to the risk of steroid-induced hyperglycemia.

Diagnosis- They can be stained with 10% potassium hydroxide and can be cultured. On Sabouraud agar at 30-37°C, they appear as grey-white colonies with a thick cottony, fluffy surface. Under the microscope, they appear as nonseptate, irregularly branched broad hyphae with aerial sporangiophores which end in a sporangium (a sac containing spores). 

Important aspects in the management of mucormycosis involve

  • Initiation of antifungal therapy- Amphotericin B is the first line, antifungal agent. Other antifungal agents used are isavuconazole and posaconazole
  • Treatment of the underlying risk factors
  • Surgical debridement

The below image shows broad aseptate and irregularly branched hyphae seen in mucormycosis

Other options:

  • The galactomannan assay is used for the diagnosis of invasive (deep-seated) mycoses, pulmonary or disseminated forms, caused by Aspergillus fumigatus, other Aspergillus species.
  • 1,3 beta D Glucan assay  -1,3-β-d-glucan (BDG) is a cell wall polysaccharide found in most fungi, more commonly in candida, aspergillus, and pneumocystis jiroveci.  
  • Enzyme immunoassay (EIA) designed to detect beta D Glucan by using purified, lysed horseshoe crab (Limulus polyphemus) amebocytes.

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text:
In a road traffic accident, a pedestrian was hit and he suffered the following injuries. Which of these sustained injuries are most likely to be secondary injuries?
  1. Fractures of tibia and fibula
  2. Tire marks on the body
  3. Head injury
  4. Lacerations by particles of the broken windshield
  5. Patterned injuries of the radiator grill
questions.solution:
The correct option is 2 and 3 only.

  • Fractures of tibia and fibula- (Bumper injury: primary impact injury)
  • Tire marks on the body- (secondary injuries)
  • Head injury- (most common secondary injury)
  • Lacerations by particles of the broken windshield- (secondary impact injury)
  • Patterned injuries of the radiator grill- (primary impact injury)

Injuries to pedestrians:

  • Primary impact injuries are caused by the first impact of the vehicle on the victim. Eg: injuries produced are patterned injuries, and are due to the bumper, radiator grill, headlights, etc.
  • Secondary impact injuries are further injuries caused by the vehicle. Eg: Particles of the broken windshield, parts of the bonnet, etc. can produce contusions, lacerations, etc
  • Tertiary impact injuries (synonyms: Secondary injuries) are caused when the victim strikes other objects or falls on the ground after being hit by the vehicle. Eg: Head injuries are the most common injuries of this group, crush injuries, Tire marks seen on the body.

A note to clear the confusion: The question is asking for Secondary injuries, which is also called Tertiary impact injuries, which happens when the victim strikes the ground. Secondary impact injuries are the impact injuries caused by the vehicle apart from primary impact injuries. For example, lacerations produced by particles of the broken windshield, in this case.

questions.text: A 50-year-old lady was diagnosed with maxillary carcinoma. While explaining the prognosis of the condition, the doctor draws a line stating that tumors situated below the line have a better prognosis than those above. Which landmarks are used to draw this line?

choices.text: Medial canthus to angle of manidble
Floor of the orbit to floor of antrum
Anterior semicircular canal to posterior semicircular canal

questions.solution:
The line used for the classification of maxillary carcinomas as described in the clinical vignette is Ohngren’s line, which passes through the medial canthus of the eye and angle of the mandible. This classification is known as Ohngren’s classification.

  • Growth situated above the plane - Suprastructure - Poor Prognosis
  • Growth situated below the plane - Infrastructure - Good Prognosis

 

Other classifications for maxillary carcinomas include:

  • AJCC (American Joint Committee on Cancer) classification for squamous cell carcinomas. It does not include nonepithelial tumours. Histopathologically, squamous cell carcinoma is further graded as well-differentiated, moderately differentiated and poorly differentiated.
  • Lederman’s classification: Two horizontal lines are drawn- one passing through the floors of orbits and the other through floors of antra- known as Sebileau's lines. Further, vertical lines are drawn down the medial walls of orbit separating ethmoid sinuses and nasal fossa from the maxillary sinuses. The area is divided into:
    • Suprastructure: Ethmoid, sphenoid, frontal sinuses and the olfactory part of the nose.
    • Mesostructure: Maxillary sinus and the respiratory part of the nose.
    • Infrastructure: Containing alveolar process.
